articles.headline: Lending Magnate Settles Fraud Case
articles.snippet: Angelo Mozilo, the former chief executive of Countrywide Financial, agreed to settle a civil fraud case against him.
articles.abstract: Angelo Mozilo, the former chief executive of Countrywide Financial, agreed to settle a civil fraud case against him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Angelo R. Mozilo, the former chief executive of Countrywide Financial, once the nation’s largest mortgage lender, agreed to pay $67.5 million on Friday to settle a civil fraud case brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission last year.

articles.headline: Avoid Foreclosure Market Until the Dust Settles
articles.snippet: There are certainly good deals in the market, but the pitfalls are many.
articles.abstract: There are certainly good deals in the market, but the pitfalls are many.
articles.lead_paragraph: Are you out of your mind to even consider buying a foreclosed property right now?

articles.headline: U.S. Will Enforce Marijuana Laws, State Vote Aside
articles.snippet: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. is the latest establishment figure to line up against a marijuana legalization initiative.
articles.abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. is the latest establishment figure to line up against a marijuana legalization initiative.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The Department of Justice says it intends to prosecute marijuana laws in California aggressively even if state voters approve an initiative on the Nov. 2 ballot to legalize the drug.

articles.headline: Capturing the Facebook Obsession
articles.snippet: The movie “The Social Network” succeeds, in part, by showing the selfishness and arrogance often displayed by young entrepreneurs.
articles.abstract: The movie “The Social Network” succeeds, in part, by showing the selfishness and arrogance often displayed by young entrepreneurs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ben Mezrich is the kind of nonfiction writer we used to call a hype artist. He takes relatively mundane subjects  counting cards in Vegas, derivatives trading, the New York Mercantile Exchange  and turns them into high-octane page-turners, replete with sex, skullduggery and plot twists worthy of James Patterson.

articles.headline: Rum Battle in Caribbean Leaves Tax Hangover
articles.snippet: Rum has set off a dispute between Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands over a tax the U.S. treasury collects on it.
articles.abstract: Rum has set off a dispute between Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands over a tax the U.S. treasury collects on it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rum and politics have made a fiery mix since America’s earliest days, when a young politician named George Washington won election to the House of Burgesses in colonial Virginia with the help of spiked punch at the polls.

articles.headline: Foreclosure Mess Draws in the Lawyers Who Handled Them
articles.snippet: Lawyers who handle mortgage cases for banks are in the cross hairs, now that big lenders are acknowledging errors in foreclosure processing.
articles.abstract: Lawyers who handle mortgage cases for banks are in the cross hairs, now that big lenders are acknowledging errors in foreclosure processing.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the rash of foreclosures across the country in recent years, many lawyers have specialized in the lucrative business of handling cases for banks and loan servicers. And now that flaws are being acknowledged by big lenders in the processing of foreclosures, some of these lawyers are finding themselves in the cross hairs of investigators  and scorned by their former clients.

articles.headline: Botox Shots Approved for Migraine
articles.snippet: Allergan, Botox’s maker, recently agreed to pay $600 million to settle allegations that it had illegally marketed the drug for unapproved uses like headaches for years.
articles.abstract: Allergan, Botox’s maker, recently agreed to pay $600 million to settle allegations that it had illegally marketed the drug for unapproved uses like headaches for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved Botox, the anti-wrinkle shot from Allergan, as a treatment to prevent chronic migraines, a little more than a month after the company agreed to pay $600 million to settle allegations that it had illegally marketed the drug for unapproved uses like headaches for years.

articles.headline: Hitler Exhibition Explores a Wider Circle of Guilt
articles.snippet: A show in Berlin focuses on the German society that nurtured and empowered the Nazi leader.
articles.abstract: A show in Berlin focuses on the German society that nurtured and empowered the Nazi leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — As artifacts go, they are mere trinkets — an old purse, playing cards, a lantern. Even the display that caused the crowds to stop and stare is a simple embroidered tapestry, stitched by village women.

articles.headline: Accused G.I.’s Were Isolated From Officers
articles.snippet: American soldiers charged with the murders of Afghan civilians operated outside their usual chain of command, interviews and documents show.
articles.abstract: American soldiers charged with the murders of Afghan civilians operated outside their usual chain of command, interviews and documents show.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Soldiers in an American Army platoon accused of murdering Afghan civilians for sport say they took orders from a ringleader who collected body parts as war trophies, were threatened with death if they spoke up and smoked hashish on their base almost daily.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and William Yardley

articles.headline: U.S. Had Warnings on Plotter of Mumbai Attack
articles.snippet: American officials received warnings from two wives of David Headley, who scouted for the Mumbai attacks that killed 163 people, that he was planning such an attack.
articles.abstract: American officials received warnings from two wives of David Headley, who scouted for the Mumbai attacks that killed 163 people, that he was planning such an attack.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez, Eric Schmitt and Ginger Thompson

articles.headline: Lincoln in Lonely Race in Arkansas
articles.snippet: Senator Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas, a former up-and-comer in the Democratic Party, has found herself largely abandoned.
articles.abstract: Senator Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas, a former up-and-comer in the Democratic Party, has found herself largely abandoned.
articles.lead_paragraph: RUSSELLVILLE, Ark.  Senator Blanche Lincoln, the incumbent Democrat  a double-whammy of a handicap this year  was hanging around the Pope County Courthouse here, looking for someone, anyone, to talk to.

articles.headline: How Countrywide Covered the Cracks
articles.snippet: Angelo R. Mozilo, Countrywide Financial’s chief executive, was publicly buoyant about its ability to ride out the mortgage crisis. Privately, he was gloomier.
articles.abstract: Angelo R. Mozilo, Countrywide Financial’s chief executive, was publicly buoyant about its ability to ride out the mortgage crisis. Privately, he was gloomier.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON June 27, 2006, Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender, was about to close its books on a record-breaking six-month run. The housing market was on fire and Countrywide’s earnings were soaring. Despite all the euphoria inside the company, some executives noticed that Angelo R. Mozilo, the company’s brash and imperious chief executive, seemed subdued.

articles.headline: Sunnis in Iraq Allied With U.S. Rejoin Rebels
articles.snippet: The loss of Sunnis from the Awakening Councils, whose switch to the government’s side helped prevent sectarian war in 2006, is a new threat.
articles.abstract: The loss of Sunnis from the Awakening Councils, whose switch to the government’s side helped prevent sectarian war in 2006, is a new threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAQUBA, Iraq  Members of United States-allied Awakening Councils have quit or been dismissed from their positions in significant numbers in recent months, prey to an intensive recruitment campaign by the Sunni insurgency, according to government officials, current and former members of the Awakening and insurgents.
articles.byline: By TIMOTHY WILLIAMS and DURAID ADNAN

articles.headline: Japan Goes From Dynamic to Disheartened
articles.snippet: Economists are pointing to Japan, which has been trapped in low growth and deflation, as a dark vision of the future for the West.
articles.abstract: Economists are pointing to Japan, which has been trapped in low growth and deflation, as a dark vision of the future for the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSAKA, Japan  Like many members of Japan’s middle class, Masato Y. enjoyed a level of affluence two decades ago that was the envy of the world. Masato, a small-business owner, bought a $500,000 condominium, vacationed in Hawaii and drove a late-model Mercedes.

articles.headline: Who Needs Cash (or Borders)?
articles.snippet: Ajay Banga, MasterCard’s new chief, is racing to take plastic to the rising middle class in India and beyond.
articles.abstract: Ajay Banga, MasterCard’s new chief, is racing to take plastic to the rising middle class in India and beyond.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: Black Turnout Will Be Crucial for Democrats
articles.snippet: Vulnerable Democrats, mostly in the rural south, want to revive the spirit of 2008 for black voters without alienating right-leaning white majorities.
articles.abstract: Vulnerable Democrats, mostly in the rural south, want to revive the spirit of 2008 for black voters without alienating right-leaning white majorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAURINBURG, N.C.  A flood of black voters in North Carolina’s Eighth Congressional District two years ago helped Barack Obama become the first Democratic presidential candidate to carry this state since Jimmy Carter and lifted the party’s Congressional challenger, Larry Kissell, to victory.

articles.headline: China Escalates Fight With U.S. on Energy Aid
articles.snippet: China dismissed the American inquiry into subsidies for clean-energy industries as election-season politics.
articles.abstract: China dismissed the American inquiry into subsidies for clean-energy industries as election-season politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  A dispute between China and the United States over Beijing’s subsidies to clean energy industries escalated on Sunday when a senior Chinese economic official warned that Washington “cannot win this trade fight.”
articles.byline: By Michael Wines and Xiyun Yang

articles.headline: When Salacious Is Irresistible
articles.snippet: A blog paid for a lewd story about Brett Favre, and then mainstream outlets followed.
articles.abstract: A blog paid for a lewd story about Brett Favre, and then mainstream outlets followed.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the last week, I’ve gotten a very clear view of two things  the male physique purported to belong to Brett Favre and the inner workings of modern media. I wish I could un-see both.

articles.headline: Redesigned, Self Adjusts Its Formula
articles.snippet: Lucy Danziger, the editor in chief of Self, does not have the luxury of moving at a leisurely pace given the field of rival active-woman magazines.
articles.abstract: Lucy Danziger, the editor in chief of Self, does not have the luxury of moving at a leisurely pace given the field of rival active-woman magazines.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a competitive triathlete and the editor in chief of Self, a magazine that offers women exclamation-pointed tips on self-fulfillment (“Banish the Blahs and Feel Happier!” “Leaner Legs! Tighter Tush!” “Be True to You!”), Lucy Danziger is not prone to idling.

articles.headline: Will Apple’s Culture Hurt the iPhone?
articles.snippet: Apple’s PC-versus-Mac battle almost put it out of business. Is it creating a similar one in the smartphone field?
articles.abstract: Apple’s PC-versus-Mac battle almost put it out of business. Is it creating a similar one in the smartphone field?
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  If you want a smartphone powered by Google’s Android software, you could get Motorola’s Droid 2 or its cousin, the Droid X. Then there is the Droid Incredible from HTC, the Fascinate from Samsung and the Ally from LG.

articles.headline: Google Is Determined to Crack the Social Code
articles.snippet: Google likes to have its finger on the pulse of the Web, and that’s becoming harder to do as users increasingly use closed networks like Facebook.
articles.abstract: Google likes to have its finger on the pulse of the Web, and that’s becoming harder to do as users increasingly use closed networks like Facebook.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google has been stunningly adept at devising computer algorithms to help people search the Internet. But when it comes to building features for social networking, the company has been much less effective.

articles.headline: New Spy Game: Firms’ Secrets Sold Overseas
articles.snippet: As countries expand efforts to gain Western technology, U.S. firms risk having employees expose secrets.
articles.abstract: As countries expand efforts to gain Western technology, U.S. firms risk having employees expose secrets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Huang Kexue, federal authorities say, is a new kind of spy.

articles.headline: White House Urges Calm on Foreclosures
articles.snippet: “A national, blanket moratorium on all foreclosure sales would do far more harm than good,” one administration member said on Sunday.
articles.abstract: “A national, blanket moratorium on all foreclosure sales would do far more harm than good,” one administration member said on Sunday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amid a rising uproar over slipshod bank foreclosure practices, members of the Obama administration on Sunday expressed anger about the revelations, but urged caution as multiple investigations into the crisis unfold.

articles.headline: Obamas Rally for Democrats in Final Push
articles.snippet: President Obama is seeking to rally anxious Democrats for the final two weeks of the midterm election campaign, and urged them not to be discouraged.
articles.abstract: President Obama is seeking to rally anxious Democrats for the final two weeks of the midterm election campaign, and urged them not to be discouraged.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama is seeking to rally anxious Democrats for the final two weeks of the midterm election campaign, traveling to the heart of the electoral battleground to urge them not to be discouraged  “Don’t let them tell you that change isn’t possible”  even as resurgent Republicans continued to expand their sights with the help of deep-pocketed allies.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: Weary of Debris, Haiti Finally Sees Some Vanish
articles.snippet: Nine months after a devastating earthquake, only now are ruins starting to be removed so rebuilding can begin.
articles.abstract: Nine months after a devastating earthquake, only now are ruins starting to be removed so rebuilding can begin.

articles.headline: ‘Culture of Poverty’ Makes a Comeback
articles.snippet: Decades after Daniel Patrick Moynihan, scholars are conceding culture and persistent poverty are enmeshed.
articles.abstract: Decades after Daniel Patrick Moynihan, scholars are conceding culture and persistent poverty are enmeshed.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than 40 years, social scientists investigating the causes of poverty have tended to treat cultural explanations like Lord Voldemort: That Which Must Not Be Named.

articles.headline: Banks Shared Clients’ Profits, but Not Losses
articles.snippet: Banks offer to help big investors like pension funds earn a little extra. When it doesn’t work, only the client loses.
articles.abstract: Banks offer to help big investors like pension funds earn a little extra. When it doesn’t work, only the client loses.
articles.lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase & Company has a proposition for the mutual funds and pension funds that oversee many Americans’ savings: Heads, we win together. Tails, you lose  alone.
